Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that President Duterte signed a measure to open a nuclear power plant in August 2020. The expert's analysis reveals that the executive order signed by the president does not mention opening a nuclear power plant but rather focuses on studying the adoption of a National Position on a Nuclear Energy Program.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the executive order signed by President Duterte is related to opening a nuclear power plant, even though the order itself does not explicitly state this. The claim makes an assumption that may not be accurate.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there was no legislative measure to open a nuclear power plant signed in August 2020, as confirmed by multiple keyword searches on the websites of the Philippine House of Representatives and Senate.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance of the executive order signed by President Duterte, as it does not directly open a nuclear power plant but rather focuses on studying the viability of nuclear energy and reviewing existing facilities.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in this claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times bias in this claim.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide an alternative explanation for the executive order signed by President Duterte.
